bibl.title: Letter from Caroline Brown to Leonard Woolf, 30th March 1944

projectDesc.p: Prepared by students of the 2025-2026 The Book in the Digital Age: Agents and Medium course, Book and Digital Media Studies, Leiden University

div.p: The letter informs Mr. Woolf that author Ahmed Ali requests permission to publish an Indian edition of Twilight in Delhi. The novel was recently recommended to British soldiers in India, ranked highly in literary competitions, and attracted interest from two Indian publishers for a 3,000-copy print run. Ali believes a local, affordable edition would increase its success.

opener.salute:
Dear Mr. WolfeWoolf
The author misspells Leonard Woolf's surname, refering to the British political theorist, author, publisher, and civil servant who founded the Hogarth Press.

div.p:
Mrs. Spencer Curtis Brown
This refers to the wife of Spencer Curtis Brown, Caroline Brown is away from the office at
the moment so I
The "I" here refers to Marth C. Janet only appearing in the letter in the signature at the bottom am writing to you in her absence. We
have received an airmail from Mr. Ahmed Ali in which he
says:
Now that TWILIGHT IN DELHI
Twilight in Delhi is Ahmed Ali's first novel, originally published in 1940, which addresses India changing social, political, and cultural climate following colonialism. has been included in
the list of books recommended to British soldiers
it should do very well indeed. This list, I find
will be distributed to all the British soldiers
in this country (India) or coming to it, and will
become operative in another couple of months. A
cheap edition therefore will be so much better and
an Indian edition, because easily available in this
country will be better still. I also discovered
that the novel won good points in a competition held
by two papers - the Illustrated Weekly of India
An English-language weekly newsmagazine publication in India (1880-1993).and
the Bombay Chronicle
An English-language important Nationalist newspaper of its time, and an important chronicler of the political upheavals of a volatile pre-independence India (1910-1959).. It was within the first twenty
books on India - which included the classics and
philosophies and other books in a Best Books com-
petition on India run by Pearl Buck
Also known as Pearl Comfort Sydenstricker Buck - American writer and humanitarian, best known for The Good Earth (1931). TWILIGHTTWILIGHT IN DELHI was
within the first ten books. Two Indian publishers
have been asking me to give them permission to bring
out an edition immediately, of 3000 copies.

He is most anxious to have your permission for this
Indian edition to be brought out and I wonder, if, in the
circumstances, you would be willing to give your consent.
